summary: This document is a compilation of news clips from August 16, 2019, covering various cases from the Southern District of New York. The primary focus is on the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death, detailing his travel patterns via Teterboro Airport, the investigation into his co-conspirators, and the conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. It also covers other cases including Michael Avenatti's extortion charges, the Panama Papers, and various other criminal proceedings.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Disgraced financier charged with sex trafficking who died by apparent suicide in the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 11, 2019.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Close friend of Epstein, alleged recruiter and manager of his network of underage girls; subject of a civil lawsuit that settled in 2017.

persons.name: David Rodgers
persons.context: One of Epstein's pilots who kept extensive flight logs from 1995 to 2013; subpoenaed and cooperated with the investigation.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Famous lawyer who helped lead Epstein's legal defense in 2007; appears in flight logs and is accused by Virginia Giuffre of sexual abuse, which he denies.

persons.name: Virginia Roberts Giuffre
persons.context: Alleged victim of Epstein who claims she was forced to have underage sex with Epstein's associates, including Alan Dershowitz.

persons.name: Larry Visoski
persons.context: Another pilot employed by Epstein; subpoenaed and cooperated with federal prosecutors.

persons.name: Leslie Wexner
persons.context: Billionaire founder of L Brands who had a close financial relationship with Epstein, granting him power of attorney; cut ties in 2007.

persons.name: Sarah Kellen
persons.context: Identified in the document as a potential co-conspirator in Epstein's 2008 plea agreement; flight logs show trips to and from Teterboro.

persons.name: Nadia Marcinkova
persons.context: Identified in the document as a potential co-conspirator in Epstein's 2008 plea agreement; flight logs show trips to and from Teterboro.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's former cellmate at MCC, a former police officer facing murder charges; cleared of wrongdoing in the July 23 incident involving Epstein.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Attorney for Nicholas Tartaglione who stated his client was cleared by the MCC internal investigation.

persons.name: Lamine N'Diaye
persons.context: Warden of the Metropolitan Correctional Center who was reassigned after Epstein's death; corresponded with Judge Richard Berman.

persons.name: Richard Berman
persons.context: Judge overseeing Epstein's federal sex trafficking case who inquired about the July 23 incident at MCC.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: U.S. Attorney General who pledged to continue the investigation into Epstein's network and reassigned the MCC warden.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.context: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York overseeing the Epstein case; also mentioned in the Avenatti case.

persons.name: Michael Avenatti
persons.context: Embattled attorney facing federal extortion charges related to Nike; accused prosecutors of selective prosecution.

persons.name: Gary Franklin Sr.
persons.context: Former youth basketball coach in California, client of Michael Avenatti in the potential lawsuit against Nike.

persons.name: Jamal James
persons.context: Former Nike EYB executive referenced in alleged texts about illicit payments to basketball players.

persons.name: Carlton Debose
persons.context: Director of Nike's EYB program referenced in alleged texts about illicit payments.

persons.name: John Stovall
persons.context: Nike's former recruiting coordinator referenced in alleged texts about illicit payments.

persons.name: Mark Geragos
persons.context: Attorney who met with Nike's attorneys with Avenatti; not charged in the extortion case.

persons.name: Harald Joachim von der Goltz
persons.context: Boston financier indicted in the Panama Papers case for tax evasion and hiding assets.

persons.name: Jeffrey Goldstein
persons.context: Manhattan osteopathic doctor who pleaded guilty to taking kickbacks from Insys Therapeutics.

persons.name: Daniel Hernandez
persons.context: Rapper known as Tekashi 6ix9ine, expected to testify as a government cooperator in a kidnapping and robbery case.

persons.name: Baktash Akasha
persons.context: Kenyan drug lord sentenced to 25 years for international drug trafficking.

persons.name: Ibrahim Akasha
persons.context: Brother of Baktash Akasha, pleaded guilty to drug trafficking charges; sentencing scheduled for November.

persons.name: Vicky Goswami
persons.context: Trusted co-conspirator of the Akasha brothers who became a cooperating witness for the government.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as Epstein's close friend, alleged recruiter and manager of his network of underage girls.
Rodgers was one of Epstein's pilots who kept detailed flight logs for his private jets.
Dershowitz helped lead Epstein's legal defense team in 2007 and appears multiple times in his flight logs.
Giuffre alleges Epstein forced her into underage sex and lent her out to associates.
Wexner granted Epstein power of attorney over his personal finances; they had a close business relationship until 2007.
Identified as a potential co-conspirator in Epstein's 2008 plea agreement.
Identified as a potential co-conspirator in Epstein's 2008 plea agreement.
Tartaglione was Epstein's cellmate at MCC during the July 23 incident.
Avenatti represented Franklin in a potential lawsuit against Nike over illicit payments.
Both attorneys met with Nike's attorneys regarding Franklin's case.
Brothers who led an international drug trafficking network together.
Goswami was a trusted co-conspirator who later became a government cooperating witness.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his jail cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in an apparent suicide.

events.title: Epstein Found Semiconscious in Cell
events.description: Epstein was found in a fetal position with marks around his neck in his MCC cell, leading to a suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Arrest at Teterboro
events.description: Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport after flying from Paris, charged with sex trafficking.

events.title: News Clips Compilation
events.description: Publication of SDNY news clips covering various cases including Epstein, Avenatti, Panama Papers, and others.

events.title: Goldstein Pleads Guilty
events.description: Doctor Jeffrey Goldstein pleaded guilty to taking kickbacks from Insys Therapeutics for prescribing Subsys.

events.title: Baktash Akasha Sentenced
events.description: Kenyan drug lord Baktash Akasha was sentenced to 25 years in prison for international drug trafficking.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), New York City
U.S. Virgin Islands (Little St. James Island)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's private jets recorded at least 730 flights to and from Teterboro Airport between 1995 and 2013, representing about a third of all his flights.
Epstein's pilots David Rodgers and Larry Visoski were subpoenaed and cooperated with federal prosecutors after his arrest.
Epstein was removed from suicide watch after the July 23 incident, prior to his death by apparent suicide on August 11, 2019.
Flight logs show Epstein's planes flew to locations including Palm Beach, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Paris, London, and Aspen, often carrying underage girls.
The document highlights inhumane conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, including isolation, poor ventilation, and inadequate mental health care.
